title: Paragraph Writing — Building Strong Body Paragraphs
description: Children learn the structure of a body paragraph: topic sentence, supporting details, and closing sentence. They practice identifying these elements in sample paragraphs and draft their own.
instructions:
1. Review: What is a paragraph? (A group of sentences about one topic.)
2. Introduce the three parts: topic sentence (tells the main idea), supporting details (give facts, examples, reasons), closing sentence (wraps it up).
3. Read a sample paragraph together. Identify the topic sentence, supporting details, and closing sentence.
4. Color-code: underline topic sentence in red, supporting details in blue, closing sentence in green.
5. Read a second sample paragraph and have the child identify the parts independently.
6. Discuss: What makes a strong supporting detail? (Specific facts, examples, or reasons — not vague statements.)
7. Child drafts a body paragraph on a topic of their choice using the three-part structure.
8. Review the draft together, checking for all three parts.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare two sample paragraphs on engaging topics (animals, sports, seasons). One should be about 5-6 sentences. Create a simple chart showing: Topic Sentence (red) -> Supporting Details (blue) -> Closing Sentence (green).

slides.text: 'A paragraph is like a sandwich. The top bun is your TOPIC SENTENCE — it tells the reader what the paragraph is about. The fillings are your SUPPORTING DETAILS — facts, examples, and reasons. The bottom bun is your CLOSING SENTENCE — it wraps everything up.'

Read the first sample paragraph aloud. 'Which sentence tells us the main idea? That is the topic sentence — underline it in RED. Which sentences give us facts or examples? Those are supporting details — underline them in BLUE. Which sentence wraps it up? That is the closing sentence — underline it in GREEN.'

Show the second sample paragraph. 'Now it is your turn. Read this paragraph and color-code it yourself. Find the topic sentence, the supporting details, and the closing sentence.' Let the child work independently, then check together.

'Now let us write your own paragraph. Pick a topic you care about — your favorite animal, a hobby, a place you love. Start with a topic sentence that states your main idea. Add three supporting details. End with a closing sentence.'

slides.prompt: Write a complete body paragraph with at least 5 sentences. Include: one clear topic sentence, three supporting details with specific facts or examples, and one closing sentence. After writing, color-code your own paragraph using red, blue, and green to check that all three parts are present.

slides.text: Every strong paragraph has a clear structure: a topic sentence that introduces the main idea, supporting details that prove or explain it, and a closing sentence that ties it together. This structure helps your reader follow your thinking. This week we will keep building our paragraph-writing skills.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify topic sentences, supporting details, and closing sentences in a paragraph and write their own with all three elements?

parent_notes: Paragraph structure is a foundational writing skill. The sandwich analogy works well for this age group. Encourage specificity in supporting details — 'Dogs are fun' is weak; 'Golden retrievers love to play fetch and swim in lakes' is strong. If the child struggles, have them tell you their ideas aloud first, then write them down. Montessori grammar work (sentence analysis) supports this skill by helping children understand how sentences work together.

title: Division Practice — Exploring Remainders with Story Problems
description: Children explore division problems that do not divide evenly using manipulatives. They discover that the leftover amount is called a remainder and learn to express it using the R notation.
instructions:
1. Review equal sharing: 12 cookies among 4 friends = 3 each. No leftovers.
2. Present: 13 cookies among 4 friends. Use counters to distribute one at a time.
3. After dealing out, 1 counter remains. Introduce the word REMAINDER.
4. Write the notation: 13 ÷ 4 = 3 R1. Explain: 3 is the quotient, 1 is the remainder.
5. Practice with manipulatives: 14 ÷ 3, 17 ÷ 5, 10 ÷ 4.
6. Discuss: Can a remainder ever be bigger than the divisor? Why not?
7. Child works through 6 more problems independently with counters.
8. Record each problem with the R notation in math journal.

items: 5 small bowls or cups for grouping
slides.setup_instructions: Set out at least 30 counters. Have the bowls ready for grouping. Write the division problems on cards or on the whiteboard ahead of time.

slides.text: 'Let us share 12 cookies among 4 friends.' Place 12 counters out and 4 bowls. Deal one counter at a time into each bowl. 'Each friend gets 3. Nothing is left over. 12 ÷ 4 = 3 exactly.'

'Now let us try 13 cookies among 4 friends.' Add one more counter. Deal again: each bowl gets 3, but one counter is left. 'Everyone has 3, but there is 1 left over. We cannot split it evenly. This leftover is called a REMAINDER.'

Write on the whiteboard: 13 ÷ 4 = 3 R1. 'The 3 is called the quotient — how many each person gets. The R1 means remainder 1 — one is left over.' Ask: 'Could the remainder ever be 4 or more? No! If we had 4 left, we could give one more to each person.'
Practice together: 14 ÷ 3. Deal 14 counters into 3 bowls. Each gets 4, remainder 2. Write: 14 ÷ 3 = 4 R2. Try 17 ÷ 5: each gets 3, remainder 2. Write: 17 ÷ 5 = 3 R2.

slides.prompt: Use your counters to solve these division problems. Write each answer using R notation in your math journal: 15 ÷ 4 = ?, 19 ÷ 6 = ?, 22 ÷ 5 = ?, 11 ÷ 3 = ?, 25 ÷ 7 = ?, 20 ÷ 6 = ?. For each problem, draw a picture showing the groups and the remainder.

slides.text: Division does not always come out even. When there is an amount left over that cannot be shared equally, we call it a remainder. The remainder is always less than the divisor. This week we will practice more with remainders and learn when they matter in real life.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child divide with manipulatives, identify the remainder, and record the answer using R notation?

parent_notes: Remainders are a critical concept bridging whole-number division and fractions or decimals. Use real-world contexts: sharing snacks, dealing cards, distributing supplies. The key rule — the remainder must be less than the divisor — helps children self-check their work. If the remainder equals or exceeds the divisor, they can deal out another round. Let the child discover this rather than just telling them.

title: The Industrial Revolution — From Hand Power to Machine Power
description: Children learn about the Industrial Revolution as a period when people shifted from making things by hand to using machines. They explore how inventions like the spinning jenny and steam engine changed work and daily life.
instructions:
1. Show a hand-spun piece of yarn or fabric. Ask: How long would it take to make a whole shirt by hand?
2. Explain that for thousands of years, everything was made by hand. Then in the 1700s in England, something changed.
3. Introduce the Industrial Revolution: 'revolution' means a huge change. This was a revolution in how things were MADE.
4. Discuss key inventions: spinning jenny (spun many threads at once), water frame, steam engine (James Watt).
5. Compare: one spinner by hand vs. one spinner with a machine — machines could do the work of many people.
6. Discuss factories: people left farms and came to cities to work in factories.
7. Child creates a before-and-after comparison chart.
8. Place the Industrial Revolution on a timeline (1760s-1840s).
materials_needed: Images of early factories and machines

slides.heading: The Industrial Revolution
slides.subheading: From Hand Power to Machine Power

items: Printed images of spinning jenny, steam engine, early factories
A piece of yarn or thread
slides.setup_instructions: Print images of key inventions: spinning jenny, steam engine, early textile factory. Have a piece of yarn to pass around. Prepare the timeline to show the 1700s-1800s period.

slides.text: Hold up the yarn. 'Imagine spinning enough thread to make one shirt. It would take WEEKS of work by hand. For thousands of years, that is how every piece of clothing was made — slowly, by hand, one thread at a time. Then something extraordinary happened in England in the 1700s.'

'It was called the INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION. Revolution means a huge, dramatic change. This revolution changed how things were MADE. Instead of one person spinning one thread, a machine called the SPINNING JENNY could spin eight threads at once! Later, it could spin even more.'

'Then came the STEAM ENGINE, improved by James Watt. Steam engines used boiling water to create power. They could run machines in factories, push trains along tracks, and move boats through water. Steam power changed EVERYTHING.'

'Because of these machines, FACTORIES were built — big buildings full of machines. People left their farms and moved to cities to work in factories. Cities grew bigger and bigger. Life changed dramatically: goods became cheaper and more available, but factory work was hard and the cities were crowded.'

slides.prompt: Create a T-chart labeled 'Before the Industrial Revolution' and 'After the Industrial Revolution.' Compare: how clothes were made, where people lived, how fast goods were produced, what powered the work, and how people traveled. Add drawings to illustrate each side. Include at least 5 comparisons.

slides.text: The Industrial Revolution was one of the biggest changes in human history. It transformed how people worked, where they lived, and what they could make. This week we will explore more about how these changes affected families and children, and how inventions kept improving.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what the Industrial Revolution was, name at least two key inventions, and describe how life changed from before to after?

parent_notes: The Industrial Revolution is a pivotal topic connecting to economics, science, geography, and social studies. Keep the focus age-appropriate: the wonder of invention and the big changes in daily life. You can briefly mention that factory conditions were often harsh, especially for children, but save deeper discussion of child labor for later. Hands-on comparisons help — try spinning yarn by hand vs. imagining a machine doing it. This connects to the Montessori Great Lesson on human needs and tendencies.

title: North America — The Continent We Call Home
description: Children study North America as a continent, identifying its major countries, physical features, and climate zones. They locate mountain ranges, rivers, deserts, and plains on a map and discuss how geography shapes how people live.
instructions:
1. Show a world map or globe. Locate North America. Review: it is one of seven continents.
2. Identify the three large countries: Canada, United States, Mexico. Point out Central America and Caribbean islands as part of North America.
3. Trace major physical features: Rocky Mountains, Appalachian Mountains, Great Plains, Mississippi River, Great Lakes, Sonoran Desert.
4. Discuss climate zones: arctic (northern Canada), temperate (most of US and southern Canada), tropical (southern Mexico, Central America).
5. Ask: How does geography affect how people live? (Mountains = mining, skiing; Plains = farming; Coasts = fishing, trade.)
6. Child labels a blank map of North America with countries and major features.
7. Add North America facts to geography notebook.
materials_needed: Blank outline map of North America

items: Blank outline map of North America
slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank outline map of North America showing country borders. Have an atlas or reference map available for the child to look up features. Prepare colored pencils: blue for water, brown for mountains, green for plains, yellow for deserts.

slides.text: 'Today we begin an in-depth study of North America — the continent where we live. Find it on the globe. North America stretches from the Arctic Ocean in the north to Central America in the south. It includes three large countries: CANADA, the UNITED STATES, and MEXICO, plus the countries of Central America and the islands of the Caribbean.'

'North America has incredible variety in its landscape. In the west, the ROCKY MOUNTAINS run like a spine from Canada to Mexico. In the east, the older APPALACHIAN MOUNTAINS stretch from Alabama to Maine. Between them lie the vast GREAT PLAINS — flat grasslands perfect for farming.'

'Water features shape our continent too. The MISSISSIPPI RIVER — the longest in North America — flows from Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico. The GREAT LAKES are the largest group of freshwater lakes in the world. And the SONORAN DESERT in the southwest is hot and dry.'

'Climate changes as you move across North America. The far north of Canada is arctic — frozen much of the year. Most of the US and southern Canada have temperate climates with four seasons. Southern Mexico and Central America are tropical — warm and wet. How does climate affect how people live, what they grow, and what they wear?'

slides.prompt: On your blank map of North America, label: Canada, United States, Mexico, Rocky Mountains (draw in brown), Appalachian Mountains (brown), Great Plains (green), Mississippi River (blue), Great Lakes (blue), Sonoran Desert (yellow). Add the Pacific Ocean on the west and Atlantic Ocean on the east. Color-code the three climate zones: arctic (light blue), temperate (green), tropical (orange).

slides.text: North America is a continent of incredible diversity — from frozen tundra to tropical rainforests, from towering mountains to vast plains. The geography of this continent has shaped where people settled, what they ate, and how they traveled. This week we will explore specific regions in more depth.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate the three main countries of North America, label major physical features on a map, and describe how geography affects how people live?

parent_notes: This lesson provides a broad overview that will be deepened throughout the week. Montessori geography moves from the whole to the parts — continent first, then countries, then regions. Physical geography is emphasized because it helps children understand WHY people settled where they did and HOW cultures developed differently. If you have puzzle maps of North America, use them. The labeling activity builds map skills and spatial awareness. Connect to any family travel experiences in North America.

title: Because of Winn-Dixie — Chapters 1-3: A Girl and Her Dog
description: Children begin Kate DiCamillo's beloved novel about Opal, a lonely girl who finds a stray dog in a Winn-Dixie supermarket. They explore themes of loneliness, new beginnings, and the bond between humans and animals.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author: Kate DiCamillo. Show the cover.
2. Ask: Have you ever felt lonely in a new place? What helped?
3. Read chapters 1-3 aloud together.
4. Discuss: Who is Opal? Where does she live? What is her family situation?
5. How does Opal find Winn-Dixie? Why does she decide to keep him?
6. Character study: What do we learn about Opal's personality from these chapters?
7. Discuss the setting: Naomi, Florida — a small Southern town.
8. Child writes or draws a response about a time they felt new or lonely.
materials_needed: Because of Winn-Dixie by Kate DiCamillo

slides.heading: Because of Winn-Dixie
slides.subheading: Chapters 1-3: A Girl and Her Dog

items: Because of Winn-Dixie by Kate DiCamillo
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Prepare a cozy reading spot. You might want to look up Naomi, Florida on a map to connect with geography studies. Bookmark chapters 1-3.

slides.text: 'Today we begin a wonderful story called Because of Winn-Dixie by Kate DiCamillo. It is about a girl named Opal who has just moved to a new town in Florida with her father, who is a preacher. She feels very lonely — until she makes an unexpected friend in a supermarket.'

Before reading, ask: 'Have you ever moved to a new place or been somewhere where you did not know anyone? How did that feel? What helped you feel better?' Listen to the child's response and connect it to what Opal will experience.

Read chapters 1-3 aloud, using distinct voices for Opal and the preacher. Pause after Opal finds the dog in the supermarket. 'What a scene! A dog running wild through the Winn-Dixie store. What would YOU have done?'

After reading, discuss: 'What do we know about Opal so far? She is ten, new in town, lives with just her father. Her mother left when she was three. Why do you think the dog is so important to her?' Guide the child to see that Winn-Dixie fills Opal's loneliness.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, create a character page for Opal. Draw a picture of her and write at least 5 things you have learned about her from chapters 1-3 (age, family, personality traits, where she lives, how she feels). Then write 2-3 sentences connecting Opal's experience to your own: have you ever found a friend in an unexpected way?

slides.text: Kate DiCamillo writes with such warmth that we already care about Opal and Winn-Dixie after just three chapters. Opal is brave, kind, and a little bit sad. Winn-Dixie is messy, lovable, and exactly the friend Opal needs. Next time we read, we will discover how the people of Naomi, Florida react to this unusual dog.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe Opal's character, explain how she found Winn-Dixie, and connect the themes of loneliness and friendship to their own experience?

parent_notes: Because of Winn-Dixie is a Newbery Honor book that beautifully explores themes of loneliness, community, and acceptance. DiCamillo's prose is simple yet profound, making it perfect for this age group. The first-person narration lets children practice empathy by seeing the world through Opal's eyes. Reading aloud together is important — even children who can read independently benefit from shared reading experiences. Pause to discuss but do not over-analyze; let the story work its magic.

title: Research Skills — Using a Table of Contents
description: Children learn how to use a table of contents to locate information in nonfiction books. They practice scanning chapter titles and page numbers to find specific topics quickly.
instructions:
1. Show several nonfiction books. Ask: If you wanted to find information about volcanoes, would you read the whole book? No — you would use tools to find the right section.
2. Open to the table of contents in one book. Explain: this is a map of the book.
3. Point out: chapter titles, page numbers, and how topics are organized.
4. Model: 'I want to find information about ocean animals. I scan the chapter titles... Chapter 5: Life in the Ocean, page 42. I turn to page 42.'
5. Give the child a different book. Ask them to find specific topics using the table of contents.
6. Compare tables of contents from 2-3 books. How are they similar? Different?
7. Child creates a table of contents for an imaginary book about their favorite subject.
8. Discuss when and why a table of contents is useful.
materials_needed: 3-4 nonfiction books with clear tables of contents

items: 3-4 nonfiction books with clear tables of contents
slides.setup_instructions: Select nonfiction books on topics interesting to the child (animals, space, history, sports). Ensure each has a clear, well-organized table of contents. Mark specific topics in each book that you will ask the child to find.

slides.text: 'When you need to find specific information in a book, you do not have to read every page. Nonfiction books have special tools to help you find what you need quickly. Today we will learn about the TABLE OF CONTENTS — a list at the beginning of a book that shows what is inside.'

Open a nonfiction book to the table of contents. 'Look at this page. It lists every chapter, its title, and the page number where it starts. The chapters are in ORDER — the first chapter is first, the last chapter is last. It is like a map of the book.'

Model the process: 'I want to learn about how butterflies change. Let me scan the chapter titles... Chapter 3: Metamorphosis, page 28. That sounds right! I turn to page 28.' Demonstrate turning to the correct page. 'It works! Now you try.'

Give the child a book and a question: 'Can you find the chapter about [specific topic]?' Let them scan the table of contents and locate the right chapter and page. Repeat with 2-3 more questions using different books.

slides.prompt: Create a table of contents for an imaginary nonfiction book about your favorite subject. Your book should have at least 6 chapters. Write a clear title for each chapter and assign page numbers. Make sure the chapters are in a logical order. Use a ruler to line up the page numbers neatly on the right side.

slides.text: A table of contents is one of the most useful tools in a nonfiction book. It saves time and helps you go straight to the information you need. Skilled researchers always check the table of contents first. Next lesson, we will learn about another powerful research tool: the INDEX.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use a table of contents to locate specific information in a nonfiction book and explain its purpose?

parent_notes: Research skills are essential for Montessori independent learning. Children at this age are transitioning from reading for enjoyment to reading for information. Teaching them how to navigate nonfiction books builds confidence and efficiency. The table of contents is the starting point — the index (next lesson) provides more specific look-up ability. Use books the child is genuinely interested in to make the practice meaningful. This skill transfers directly to using textbooks, encyclopedias, and even website navigation.

title: Division with Remainders — Real-World Word Problems
description: Children apply division with remainders to real-world scenarios, learning that the context determines what to do with the remainder: sometimes round up, sometimes drop it, sometimes express it as a fraction.
instructions:
1. Review remainder notation from yesterday: 13 ÷ 4 = 3 R1.
2. Present problem: 23 students need to ride in vans that hold 6. How many vans? 23 ÷ 6 = 3 R5. Do we need 3 vans or 4? (4 — we cannot leave 5 students behind!)
3. Present problem: You have 20 stickers to share among 3 friends. How many does each get? 20 ÷ 3 = 6 R2. Each gets 6. The 2 extra are just left over.
4. Present problem: 17 inches of ribbon cut into 5-inch pieces. How many pieces? 17 ÷ 5 = 3 R2. You get 3 full pieces.
5. Discuss: The remainder means different things depending on the situation.
6. Child categorizes problems by what to do with the remainder.
7. Child creates their own word problems with remainders.

slides.heading: Remainders in Real Life
slides.subheading: What Do We Do with Leftovers?

slides.setup_instructions: Write 6-8 word problems on cards, mixing the three remainder types: round up (need an extra group), drop it (leftover is unused), or express as fraction. Include contexts like transportation, sharing food, cutting materials.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned that division sometimes has leftovers — remainders. But here is the interesting part: in real life, what you DO with the remainder depends on the situation. Let me show you three different kinds.'

Problem 1: '23 students need rides in vans. Each van holds 6 students. How many vans do we need?' Solve: 23 ÷ 6 = 3 R5. 'Three vans hold 18 students, but 5 are left. Can we leave them behind? No! We need a FOURTH van. So the answer is 4 vans. Sometimes we ROUND UP.'

Problem 2: '20 stickers shared among 3 friends equally. How many does each friend get?' Solve: 20 ÷ 3 = 6 R2. 'Each friend gets 6 stickers. The 2 extra just stay in the pack. The answer is 6 stickers each. Sometimes we IGNORE the remainder.'

Problem 3: '17 inches of ribbon cut into 5-inch pieces. How many full pieces can you cut?' Solve: 17 ÷ 5 = 3 R2. 'You get 3 full pieces. The leftover 2 inches is too short. The answer is 3 pieces. Sometimes the remainder is just a leftover scrap.'

slides.prompt: Solve each word problem and decide what to do with the remainder — round up, ignore it, or express the leftover: (1) 29 children sit at tables of 4. How many tables needed? (2) 50 marbles shared among 8 children. How many each? (3) A baker has 35 eggs. Each cake needs 6 eggs. How many cakes? (4) 22 feet of rope cut into 7-foot jump ropes. How many jump ropes? Write 2 of your own word problems with remainders.

slides.text: The remainder is not just a leftover number — it carries meaning. Sometimes you need to round up because you cannot leave people or things behind. Sometimes you just drop it because the extra cannot be used. Learning to interpret remainders is an important part of mathematical thinking.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child solve division word problems with remainders and correctly interpret what to do with the remainder based on context?

parent_notes: Interpreting remainders is a higher-order thinking skill that many standardized tests assess. The three contexts (round up, drop it, express as fraction) require children to think beyond calculation to meaning. Encourage the child to act out problems physically when possible — actually dealing out counters helps them see why the remainder matters. Creating their own word problems is excellent practice because it requires understanding the concept deeply enough to generate new examples.

title: The Skeletal System — Our Body's Framework
description: Children explore the human skeletal system, learning that bones provide structure, protect organs, and work with muscles to allow movement. They identify major bones and learn how bones grow and heal.
instructions:
1. Ask: What would happen if you had no bones? (We would be like a jellyfish — no shape.)
2. Introduce the skeletal system: 206 bones in an adult, about 270 in a baby (some fuse together).
3. Show a skeleton diagram. Identify major bones: skull, spine (vertebrae), ribs, pelvis, femur, tibia, humerus, radius, ulna.
4. Three jobs of the skeleton: support (holds you up), protection (skull protects brain, ribs protect heart and lungs), movement (bones are levers for muscles).
5. Feel your own bones: skull, collarbone, kneecap, elbow, ribs.
6. Discuss how bones grow and heal: living tissue, blood vessels inside, can mend when broken.
7. Child labels a skeleton diagram and writes the three functions.
8. Optional: feel a real bone (chicken bone) to observe structure.

items: Optional: cleaned chicken leg bone and magnifying glass
slides.setup_instructions: Print both a labeled skeleton diagram for reference and a blank one for the child to label. If using a chicken bone, boil and clean it ahead of time. You can also cut one lengthwise (carefully) to show the interior structure.

slides.text: 'Stand up straight. Now try to imagine having NO bones at all. What would happen? You would collapse like a puddle! Your bones are your body's FRAMEWORK — like the frame of a house. Without them, you could not stand, walk, or even sit. Your skeletal system has 206 bones, and today we are going to learn about them.'

'Your skeleton does THREE important jobs. First: SUPPORT — it holds your body upright and gives you shape. Second: PROTECTION — your skull is like a helmet for your brain, your ribs are a cage protecting your heart and lungs. Third: MOVEMENT — your bones work with muscles like levers and pulleys to let you run, jump, and wave.'

Show the labeled diagram. 'Let us learn some important bones. The SKULL protects your brain. The SPINE is a column of small bones called VERTEBRAE — feel them on your back. The RIBS curve around to protect your heart and lungs. The FEMUR in your thigh is the longest, strongest bone in your body.'

'Bones are ALIVE! They have blood vessels inside and they grow as you grow. A baby has about 270 bones — more than an adult! Some fuse together as you grow. If a bone breaks, it can HEAL itself. Your body sends special cells to mend the break. That is why a cast holds the bone still — so it heals straight.'

slides.prompt: Label these bones on your blank skeleton diagram: skull, spine (vertebrae), ribs, pelvis, femur, tibia, humerus, radius, ulna, clavicle (collarbone), patella (kneecap). Color the bones that provide PROTECTION in blue and the bones involved in LEG MOVEMENT in red. In your science notebook, write the three functions of the skeleton with an example of each.

slides.text: Your skeleton is an incredible living structure — 206 bones working together to support you, protect your vital organs, and allow you to move. Bones are not dry and dead; they are alive, growing, and able to heal. Next time, we will learn about the MUSCULAR system — the partner that works with bones to make movement happen.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 8 major bones, explain the three functions of the skeleton, and describe how bones are living tissue that grows and heals?

parent_notes: The human body is endlessly fascinating to children this age. Make it hands-on: feel your own bones through the skin (collarbone, kneecap, ribs, skull). A cleaned chicken bone is a wonderful teaching tool — children can see that bones are not solid white sticks but have spongy tissue inside (marrow) and are covered in a thin layer (periosteum). If you have access to X-rays, those are captivating. The Montessori approach emphasizes wonder: the human body is an incredible machine, and the skeleton is its framework.

title: Printmaking — Introduction to Stamping and Relief Prints
description: Children learn about printmaking as an art form where an image is transferred from one surface to another. They create simple relief prints using foam trays, exploring how reversed images and repeated patterns work.
instructions:
1. Introduce printmaking: art made by transferring an image from one surface to another. Used for centuries to make books, posters, fabric patterns.
2. Show examples of prints: woodcuts, stamps, fabric prints.
3. Explain relief printing: you carve away what you do NOT want to print. The raised parts get ink and press onto paper.
4. Demonstrate: draw a simple design on a foam tray using a pencil (pressing firmly to create grooves). Roll ink or paint over the surface. Press paper on top and rub gently. Peel to reveal the print.
5. Discuss: the image is REVERSED (mirror image). Show how letters come out backward.
6. Child creates their own design and makes multiple prints.
7. Experiment with different colors and overlapping prints.
8. Clean up and display prints to dry.
materials_needed: Tempera paint or block printing ink

items: Pencil or blunt stylus for drawing
Tempera paint or block printing ink
slides.setup_instructions: Cut the flat centers from styrofoam trays, trimming away curved edges. Cover the workspace with newspaper. Squeeze paint onto a flat surface (a plate or tray) for rolling. Have paper towels ready for cleanup. Pre-make one print to show the child the finished result.

slides.text: 'For thousands of years, artists have used PRINTMAKING to create art. Instead of drawing one picture, printmaking lets you make MANY copies of the same image. Books, posters, wallpaper, and fabric patterns are all made using printing. Today, you will become a printmaker!'

'We are making RELIEF PRINTS. In a relief print, you carve into a surface. The parts you carve AWAY will stay white. The parts that stay RAISED will get ink and print onto the paper. Think of it like a rubber stamp — the raised letters leave a mark.'

Demonstrate: 'I will draw a simple design — a star — pressing firmly with my pencil into the foam. See how the pencil makes grooves? Those grooves will NOT print. Now I roll paint over the whole surface. The grooves stay empty, but the flat surface picks up the paint.'

Press paper onto the inked surface and rub gently. Peel it off carefully. 'Look! The star appears! But notice something: the image is REVERSED — it is a mirror image. If you write a word, it will come out backward! That is why printmakers have to think in reverse.'

slides.prompt: Design your own relief print on a foam tray. Draw a simple, bold image (a flower, animal, pattern, or your initials). Remember that your image will be reversed when printed. Press firmly to create grooves. Roll paint over your design and make at least 3 prints. Try: different colors, printing on colored paper, or overlapping two prints to create a layered design.

slides.text: You are now a printmaker! Relief printing has been used for hundreds of years. Gutenberg used a similar technique to print the first books in Europe. Artists today still love printmaking because each print is unique — slightly different from the last. Keep your foam plate; you can use it to make more prints anytime.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what relief printing is, create a design on a foam surface, and successfully transfer it to paper as a print?

parent_notes: Printmaking is a wonderful art form for children because it combines design thinking with hands-on process. The reversed-image concept is an excellent brain exercise. Start with simple, bold designs — fine details do not print well with this method. If you do not have a brayer, you can use a foam paint roller or even spread paint with a brush (though results are less even). Styrofoam trays from grocery packaging work perfectly and are free. This connects to history studies: the printing press revolutionized communication during the Renaissance and Industrial Revolution.

title: Meal Planning — Creating a Balanced Weekly Menu
description: Children learn the basics of meal planning by creating a balanced menu for one week. They consider food groups, nutrition, family preferences, and seasonal ingredients while developing organizational and planning skills.
instructions:
1. Discuss: Why do we plan meals? (Save time, eat healthy, reduce waste, save money.)
2. Review the five food groups: fruits, vegetables, grains, protein, dairy. A balanced meal includes at least three groups.
3. Show a sample daily menu: breakfast, lunch, dinner, and one snack.
4. Brainstorm together: What meals does your family enjoy? List favorites.
5. Introduce the concept of variety: different proteins, different vegetables through the week.
6. Child plans meals for 3 days, ensuring balance and variety.
7. Create a neat, organized menu on paper or a chart.
8. Bonus: make a grocery list for one day's meals.

items: Paper or printed meal planning template
Optional: grocery store flyer for ideas
slides.setup_instructions: Create or print a simple weekly meal planning grid (days across the top, meals down the side). Have a food group chart visible. If available, gather a grocery flyer or cookbook for inspiration. This is a great lesson to do together in the kitchen.

slides.text: 'Every day, your family needs to eat breakfast, lunch, dinner, and probably a snack or two. That is a LOT of meals! Good cooks and parents PLAN their meals ahead of time. Why? It saves time (no standing in front of the fridge wondering what to make), saves money (you buy only what you need), and helps you eat HEALTHY.'

'A balanced meal includes foods from at least three of the five food groups: FRUITS, VEGETABLES, GRAINS (bread, rice, pasta), PROTEIN (meat, beans, eggs, nuts), and DAIRY (milk, cheese, yogurt). Let us look at a sample: grilled chicken (protein), rice (grain), broccoli (vegetable), and milk (dairy). That hits four groups!'

'Variety is important too. If you eat chicken every night, you miss out on nutrients from fish, beans, and eggs. If you only eat apples, you miss what oranges and berries offer. A good meal planner uses DIFFERENT foods throughout the week.'

'Let us start planning! First, think about what your family likes to eat. Then think about balance — are there enough vegetables? Enough variety? Let us plan breakfast, lunch, dinner, and one snack for three days.' Work together, letting the child make choices while guiding toward balance.

slides.prompt: Plan meals for 3 days: breakfast, lunch, dinner, and one snack each day. For each meal, list the foods and color-code by food group (green = vegetables, red = fruits, brown = grains, blue = protein, yellow = dairy). Check: does each meal have at least 3 food groups? Is there variety across the 3 days? Then make a grocery list for Day 1's meals.

slides.text: Meal planning is a real-life skill that combines nutrition knowledge, organizational thinking, and creativity. Professional chefs, school cafeterias, and families all plan meals. You now know how to create balanced, varied menus. This week, try helping your family plan meals for real!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child plan balanced meals that include multiple food groups, demonstrate variety across days, and create a basic grocery list?

parent_notes: Meal planning is an excellent Montessori practical life activity that integrates math (budgeting, measuring), science (nutrition), and executive function (planning, organizing). Let the child's choices drive the process while gently guiding toward balance. This is a wonderful opportunity to involve the child in real family meal planning. If the child is interested, extend to budgeting (looking at prices in a flyer) or cooking one of their planned meals. The skills of planning ahead, considering multiple factors, and organizing information are valuable far beyond the kitchen.

title: Research Skills — Using an Index to Find Specific Information
description: Children learn how to use a book index to locate specific information quickly. They compare the index to the table of contents and practice looking up topics alphabetically.
instructions:
1. Review: Yesterday we used the table of contents to find chapters. Today we learn an even more specific tool: the INDEX.
2. Open to the index of a nonfiction book (in the back). Show how topics are listed alphabetically with page numbers.
3. Compare: Table of contents = broad chapters in order. Index = specific topics in alphabetical order.
4. Model: 'I want to find information about photosynthesis. I look under P... Photosynthesis, pages 34-36, 52.'
5. Explain sub-entries and cross-references ('see also').
6. Child practices looking up 5-6 specific topics in different books' indexes.
7. Time challenge: Who can find the information faster — using the index or flipping through pages?
8. Child creates a mini-index for a familiar book.

slides.setup_instructions: Choose books with substantial indexes (20+ entries). Prepare a list of specific topics to look up in each book. Have the books tabbed at the index page for quick access.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we used the TABLE OF CONTENTS at the front of a book to find chapters. But what if you need very specific information — not a whole chapter, but one fact? That is where the INDEX comes in. Open to the very BACK of this book.'

'The index lists SPECIFIC TOPICS in ALPHABETICAL ORDER with the exact page numbers where they appear. Look: it is not organized by chapter order — it is organized like a dictionary, from A to Z. Some topics appear on multiple pages, so you might see: Butterflies, 14, 27-29, 45.'

Model a lookup: 'I want to find information about migration. I go to M... ma, me, mi — migration! Pages 38-42 and 67. Now I know exactly where to look. Some entries also say "see also hibernation" — that means related information is under a different word.'

'How is the index different from the table of contents? The table of contents shows CHAPTERS in ORDER. The index shows SPECIFIC TOPICS in ALPHABETICAL order. The table of contents is like a road map. The index is like a GPS that takes you to the exact spot.'

slides.prompt: Look up these topics in your books' indexes and write down the page numbers: (1) Find a topic starting with B, (2) Find a topic starting with S, (3) Find a topic that appears on 3 or more pages, (4) Find a cross-reference ('see also'). Then create a mini-index of 10 entries for a book you have read, listing topics alphabetically with made-up page numbers.

slides.text: The index is a researcher's best friend. It lets you go straight to the exact information you need without reading the whole book. Remember: table of contents for the big picture (chapters), index for specific details (topics). Skilled researchers use both. You now have two powerful tools for finding information in books!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate specific topics using a book index, explain the difference between an index and table of contents, and navigate alphabetical listings with sub-entries?

parent_notes: Index skills transfer directly to digital literacy — search functions, databases, and website navigation all work on similar principles. The alphabetical organization reinforces letter-order knowledge. Some children struggle with guide words and sub-entries; practice with simpler indexes first. The mini-index creation activity deepens understanding because the child must think about what topics are important and how to organize them. This pairs well with any research project the child undertakes.

title: Equivalent Fractions — Same Amount, Different Names
description: Children discover that fractions can look different but represent the same amount. Using fraction strips and visual models, they find that 1/2 = 2/4 = 3/6 and explore the pattern of multiplying numerator and denominator by the same number.
instructions:
1. Show a fraction strip for 1/2. Ask: Can you find other fractions that are exactly the same size?
2. Line up fraction strips: 1/2 = 2/4 = 3/6 = 4/8. These all cover the same amount.
3. Introduce the term EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS: different names for the same amount.
4. Show the pattern: 1/2 — multiply top and bottom by 2 gives 2/4; by 3 gives 3/6; by 4 gives 4/8.
5. Try with 1/3: find equivalent fractions (2/6, 3/9, 4/12).
6. Verify each with fraction strips.
7. Introduce simplifying: 4/8 can be reduced to 1/2 by dividing top and bottom by 4.
8. Child finds equivalent fractions for given fractions and verifies with strips.

items: Fraction strips or fraction circles (halves through twelfths)
slides.setup_instructions: Lay out fraction strips in order: whole, halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, eighths, twelfths. Ensure the strips are proportionally accurate so equivalencies are visually clear. A fraction wall chart is also helpful.

slides.text: 'Look at this 1/2 strip. It covers exactly half of the whole. Now, can you find OTHER fraction strips that cover the same amount?' Let the child experiment. They should discover that 2/4, 3/6, and 4/8 all line up perfectly with 1/2.

'Amazing! 1/2, 2/4, 3/6, and 4/8 all represent the SAME AMOUNT, even though they look different. These are called EQUIVALENT FRACTIONS — fractions that are equal in value but written with different numbers. It is like how 'ten' and 'a dozen minus two' are different ways to say the same number.'

'There is a pattern here. Watch: 1/2 — multiply the top and bottom by 2: 1x2 = 2, 2x2 = 4, so we get 2/4. Multiply by 3: 1x3 = 3, 2x3 = 6, so we get 3/6. As long as you multiply TOP AND BOTTOM by the SAME NUMBER, you get an equivalent fraction.'

'We can also go backward — SIMPLIFY. If I have 6/8, I can divide top and bottom by 2: 6÷2 = 3, 8÷2 = 4. So 6/8 = 3/4. Verify with fraction strips! Simplifying means finding the fraction with the smallest possible numbers.'

slides.prompt: Find three equivalent fractions for each: 1/3 = ?/? = ?/? = ?/?, 2/5 = ?/? = ?/?, 3/4 = ?/? = ?/?. Verify each one with fraction strips. Then simplify these fractions to their simplest form: 4/6, 6/9, 8/12, 2/8, 10/15. Draw a fraction strip picture for each set of equivalents.

slides.text: Equivalent fractions are one of the most important ideas in mathematics. The same amount can be written in many different ways. Knowing how to find equivalent fractions and simplify them will help you compare fractions, add fractions, and solve many kinds of problems. The key rule: multiply or divide the numerator and denominator by the same number.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find equivalent fractions by multiplying numerator and denominator by the same number, verify with manipulatives, and simplify fractions?

parent_notes: Equivalent fractions are foundational for fraction operations (addition, subtraction, comparison). The manipulative verification is essential — do not skip it. Children need to SEE that 2/4 and 1/2 are the same before the algorithm makes sense. Common misconceptions: thinking that 1/3 and 1/6 are equivalent because 3+3=6 (they are not — you must multiply, not add). The fraction strips provide self-correction. Once the child is comfortable, reduce reliance on strips and move toward the numerical pattern.

title: The Industrial Revolution — Children, Factories, and Reform
description: Children learn about the impact of the Industrial Revolution on families and especially on children who worked in factories and mines. They explore how reformers fought for child labor laws and better working conditions.
instructions:
1. Review: What was the Industrial Revolution? (Shift from hand-made to machine-made goods.)
2. Explain that factories needed workers — and many of those workers were CHILDREN as young as 5 or 6.
3. Describe conditions sensitively: long hours (12-16 hours), dangerous machines, little pay, no school.
4. Show age-appropriate images of children in factories and mines.
5. Ask: How is your life different from a factory child's life?
6. Introduce reformers: people who said 'This is wrong!' and fought for change. Factory Acts limited children's hours and required some schooling.
7. Discuss: Why were these reforms important? How did they change childhood?
8. Child writes a diary entry from the perspective of a child factory worker.

items: Age-appropriate images of child laborers in factories and mines
slides.setup_instructions: Select images carefully — show the reality of child labor without graphic or traumatic content. Lewis Hine's photographs (early 1900s American child labor) are powerful and widely available. Prepare to discuss this sensitive topic with empathy while emphasizing the reformers who brought change.

slides.text: 'Last time we learned about the amazing inventions of the Industrial Revolution. But today we learn about a DARK side of this period. Factories needed workers, and many of those workers were CHILDREN — some as young as five years old. Let us learn what life was like for these children.'

'Children worked 12 to 16 hours a day, six days a week. They operated dangerous machines, crawled into tight spaces in mines, and cleaned under running equipment. They were paid very little. Many had no time for school or play. Some were hurt by the machines.'

'Think about YOUR day. You wake up, eat breakfast, learn, play, read, and go to bed at a reasonable time. Now imagine: waking up at 5 AM, walking to a factory in the dark, working until 7 PM, then walking home exhausted. That was the life of many children during the Industrial Revolution.'

'But brave people said THIS IS WRONG. They were called REFORMERS. People like Robert Owen and Lord Shaftesbury fought for laws to protect children. The Factory Acts limited how many hours children could work and required that young children attend school. These laws changed everything — they helped create the childhood YOU enjoy today.'

slides.prompt: Write a diary entry as a 9-year-old child working in a cotton factory in England in the 1820s. Include: what time you wake up, what your work is like, what you eat, how you feel, and what you wish for. Then write a second short paragraph as yourself, comparing your daily life to theirs. What are you grateful for?

slides.text: The story of child labor is sad, but it is also a story of HOPE. People saw injustice and fought to change it. The laws protecting children were hard-won victories. Today, organizations around the world still work to end child labor in places where it continues. Every child deserves an education and a childhood.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the conditions child laborers faced during the Industrial Revolution, explain who the reformers were, and reflect on how child labor laws changed childhood?

parent_notes: This is a sensitive topic that can be deeply moving for children. Present it honestly but age-appropriately — focus on empathy and the triumph of reform rather than graphic suffering. Children at this age have a strong sense of justice, and learning about child labor often sparks passionate responses. Connect to the Montessori value of cosmic education: understanding humanity's struggles helps us appreciate progress and inspires us to continue working for justice. If the child becomes upset, acknowledge their feelings and emphasize that reformers succeeded in creating change.

title: North American Waterways — Rivers, Lakes, and Coasts
description: Children study the major waterways of North America, learning how rivers, lakes, and coastlines have shaped settlement, trade, and transportation. They trace the Mississippi, St. Lawrence, Colorado, and Rio Grande rivers on maps.
instructions:
1. Review the map from Monday. Focus on water features today.
2. Discuss why waterways matter: drinking water, transportation, trade, farming (irrigation), power (hydroelectric).
3. Trace the Mississippi River from Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico. It was a major highway for Native Americans and settlers.
4. Study the Great Lakes: Superior, Michigan, Huron, Erie, Ontario (HOMES mnemonic). Connected to the Atlantic by the St. Lawrence River.
5. Trace the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon. Discuss how it carved the canyon over millions of years.
6. Trace the Rio Grande — it forms part of the US-Mexico border.
7. Discuss coastlines: Atlantic, Pacific, Gulf of Mexico, Arctic.
8. Child draws and labels the major waterways on a map.
materials_needed: Map of North America showing waterways

items: Detailed map of North America showing rivers and lakes
Blank outline map of North America
slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank outline map that shows river paths lightly (or have the child trace from an atlas). Prepare blue markers or pencils. Have the reference map visible for the child to compare against.

slides.text: 'Water is LIFE. Every great civilization settled near water. Today we study the incredible waterways of North America — rivers, lakes, and coastlines that shaped where people lived, how they traveled, and how they traded goods.'

'The MISSISSIPPI RIVER is the most important river in North America. It starts as a tiny stream in Minnesota and flows 2,340 miles south to the Gulf of Mexico. Native Americans called it the "Father of Waters." Steamboats carried goods up and down this river for decades. Trace it on your map.'

'The GREAT LAKES are five enormous lakes along the US-Canada border. Remember their names with HOMES: Huron, Ontario, Michigan, Erie, Superior. Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake by surface area in the world! The ST. LAWRENCE RIVER connects the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean.'

'In the west, the COLORADO RIVER carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years. In the south, the RIO GRANDE flows along the border between the US and Mexico. And North America has THREE major coastlines: the Atlantic Ocean on the east, the Pacific Ocean on the west, and the Gulf of Mexico in the south.'

slides.prompt: On your blank map, draw and label in blue: Mississippi River, Missouri River, Ohio River, St. Lawrence River, Colorado River, Rio Grande, Columbia River. Label the Great Lakes (use the HOMES mnemonic). Label the three coastlines: Atlantic, Pacific, Gulf of Mexico. Add arrows showing which direction each major river flows. In your notebook, write why waterways were important to early settlers (give 3 reasons).

slides.text: North America's waterways are like a network of highways made by nature. Rivers carried people, goods, and ideas across the continent long before roads or railroads existed. The Great Lakes hold one-fifth of the world's fresh surface water. Understanding waterways helps us understand history, trade, and how communities developed.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate and name major North American rivers and lakes on a map, and explain how waterways influenced settlement and trade?

parent_notes: Waterways are a powerful lens for understanding history and geography together. Children at this age can grasp that rivers were the original highways — the Mississippi carried Native American canoes, French fur traders, and American steamboats. The Great Lakes mnemonic (HOMES) is a classic memory aid. If possible, look up your own region's nearest major waterway and discuss its role in local history. The Colorado River and Grand Canyon connection wonderfully integrates geology with geography.

title: Because of Winn-Dixie — Chapters 4-7: Making Friends in Naomi
description: Children continue reading as Opal begins meeting the colorful characters of Naomi, Florida. They explore how Winn-Dixie helps Opal connect with others and discuss how animals can bridge gaps between people.
instructions:
1. Review: What happened in chapters 1-3? (Opal found Winn-Dixie in the supermarket, convinced her father to keep him.)
2. Read chapters 4-7 aloud together.
3. Discuss new characters: Miss Franny Block (the librarian), the Dewberry boys. How does Opal meet each one?
4. Notice Winn-Dixie's role: he is often the reason Opal meets someone new.
5. Character traits: What is Miss Franny like? Why does she tell the bear story?
6. Discuss the theme: Sometimes animals help us connect with people.
7. Child adds new characters to their reading journal.
8. Prediction: What other people might Opal meet because of Winn-Dixie?
materials_needed: Because of Winn-Dixie by Kate DiCamillo

items: Because of Winn-Dixie by Kate DiCamillo
slides.setup_instructions: Review chapters 1-3 briefly before starting. Bookmark chapters 4-7. Have the reading journal open to the character page started last session.

slides.text: 'Last time, Opal found Winn-Dixie and brought him home. She is still new in Naomi, Florida, and she does not have any friends yet. Let us see what happens next.' Briefly recap the key events from chapters 1-3.

Read chapters 4-7 aloud. Use distinct voices: Opal is earnest and thoughtful, Miss Franny Block is elderly and a bit nervous, the Dewberry boys are mischievous. Pause after Miss Franny tells the bear story. 'What a story! Do you think it is true?'

After reading, discuss: 'How did Opal meet Miss Franny Block? What role did Winn-Dixie play? Notice a pattern: Winn-Dixie keeps bringing Opal and other people together. He is like a bridge between Opal and the community.'

'The title of this book is Because of Winn-Dixie. Why do you think DiCamillo chose that title? Everything good that happens to Opal happens BECAUSE OF Winn-Dixie. He is not just a pet — he is the reason Opal's life is changing.'

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, add character pages for Miss Franny Block and the Dewberry boys. Draw each character and write 3-4 facts about them. Then create a web diagram with Winn-Dixie in the center and lines connecting to each person Opal has met because of him. Write a prediction: who else might Opal meet because of her dog?

slides.text: Winn-Dixie is more than just a dog in this story — he is a catalyst, someone (or something) that makes things happen. Because of him, Opal is no longer alone. She is building connections one person at a time. As we keep reading, watch for how each new friendship changes Opal.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the new characters introduced, explain Winn-Dixie's role in connecting Opal with others, and make predictions about the story?

parent_notes: These chapters introduce the pattern that gives the book its title: Winn-Dixie is the catalyst for every friendship Opal makes. Miss Franny Block is a particularly rich character — a librarian who loves stories. Her bear story is a wonderful example of oral storytelling tradition. Encourage the child to notice how DiCamillo reveals character through dialogue and action rather than telling us directly. The Dewberry boys represent a common childhood challenge: dealing with children who tease.

title: Prefixes — Unlocking Word Meanings with Un-, Re-, Pre-, Dis-
description: Children learn that prefixes are word parts added to the beginning of a word to change its meaning. They study four common prefixes and practice using them to decode unfamiliar words.
instructions:
1. Write 'happy' on the board. Add 'un-' to make 'unhappy.' Ask: How did the meaning change? (Opposite.)
2. Define PREFIX: a word part added to the BEGINNING of a word that changes its meaning.
3. Teach four prefixes: un- (not, opposite), re- (again), pre- (before), dis- (not, opposite).
4. For each prefix, give 4-5 examples: unhappy, unkind, unlock; rewrite, redo, replay; preview, preschool, prepay; disagree, disappear, dislike.
5. Practice: Give a word, child adds a prefix and explains the new meaning.
6. Word building game: How many words can you make with these prefixes?
7. Child creates a prefix chart with definitions and examples.
8. Read a passage and identify all prefixed words.

items: Prefix cards: un-, re-, pre-, dis-
Base word cards: happy, write, view, agree, kind, do, pay, like, lock, play, heat, appear, read, connect, tie
slides.setup_instructions: Create prefix cards (large, one prefix per card) and base word cards. You can also write them on index cards. Prepare a short passage (3-4 sentences) containing several prefixed words for the identification activity.

slides.text: 'You already know thousands of words. But did you know that by learning just a few PREFIXES, you can understand THOUSANDS more? A prefix is a word part added to the BEGINNING of a word that changes its meaning. Watch: happy means feeling good. Add UN- to the beginning: UN-happy means NOT happy. One small prefix changed the whole meaning!'

'Let us learn four super-powerful prefixes. UN- means NOT or THE OPPOSITE: unkind, untie, unsafe. RE- means AGAIN: rewrite means write again, replay means play again, reheat means heat again. These two alone open up hundreds of words!'

'Two more: PRE- means BEFORE: preview means view before, preheat means heat before, preschool means before school. DIS- means NOT or THE OPPOSITE: disagree means not agree, disappear means the opposite of appear, dislike means not like.'

Word building game: hold up base word cards. 'What prefix can we add to this word? What does the new word mean?' Try: write (rewrite), happy (unhappy), view (preview), agree (disagree), heat (preheat, reheat), connect (disconnect, reconnect). Some words can take more than one prefix!

slides.prompt: Create a PREFIX CHART with four columns, one for each prefix (un-, re-, pre-, dis-). Write the meaning of each prefix at the top. Then list at least 5 words for each prefix. For each word, write the base word and the new meaning. Example: un- (not/opposite) | unhappy = not happy, unkind = not kind. Challenge: find a word that can take TWO different prefixes (like connect: disconnect, reconnect).

slides.text: Prefixes are like secret codes — once you know what un-, re-, pre-, and dis- mean, you can figure out the meaning of words you have never seen before. If you see 'prearrange,' you know it means to arrange BEFORE. If you see 'reconnect,' you know it means to connect AGAIN. You just multiplied your vocabulary power!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define the four prefixes (un-, re-, pre-, dis-), add them to base words correctly, and explain how the prefix changes the word's meaning?

parent_notes: Prefix and suffix knowledge is one of the most efficient ways to expand vocabulary. Research shows that just four prefixes (un-, re-, in/im-, dis-) account for 58% of all prefixed words in English. Montessori word study aligns perfectly with this — the grammar boxes and word study materials build morphological awareness. Encourage the child to be a 'prefix detective' in their everyday reading, spotting and decoding prefixed words. This knowledge will also help with spelling: knowing that 'unhappy' is un + happy prevents misspellings.

title: Comparing Fractions — Which Is Greater?
description: Children learn strategies for comparing fractions: using fraction strips for visual comparison, finding common denominators, and comparing fractions with the same numerator. They use the symbols <, >, and = to record comparisons.
instructions:
1. Present two fractions: 1/3 and 1/4. Which is bigger? Use fraction strips to compare.
2. Key insight: When numerators are the same, the fraction with the SMALLER denominator is LARGER (bigger pieces).
3. Compare 2/3 and 3/4. These are harder. Use fraction strips to line them up.
4. Introduce common denominators: convert both to twelfths. 2/3 = 8/12, 3/4 = 9/12. Now compare: 8/12 < 9/12.
5. Practice the symbols: < (less than), > (greater than), = (equal).
6. Compare using benchmark fractions: Is the fraction more or less than 1/2?
7. Child compares 8 pairs of fractions using strips and then with common denominators.
8. Record each comparison with the correct symbol.

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange fraction strips in a visible display. Prepare pairs of fractions to compare, ranging from easy (same denominator) to challenging (unlike denominators). Have the comparison symbol cards ready.

slides.text: 'Which is bigger: 1/3 or 1/4?' Place both fraction strips side by side. The 1/3 piece is clearly longer. 'When the TOP numbers (numerators) are the SAME, the fraction with the SMALLER bottom number (denominator) is actually BIGGER. Why? Because you are cutting the whole into fewer pieces, so each piece is larger.'

'But what about 2/3 and 3/4? The numerators are different AND the denominators are different. Let us use fraction strips.' Line them up: 2/3 is a little bit less than 3/4. 'But can we prove this with numbers, not just strips?'

'We can give them a COMMON DENOMINATOR — the same-sized pieces. What number works for both 3 and 4? Twelve! 2/3 = 8/12 (multiply top and bottom by 4). 3/4 = 9/12 (multiply top and bottom by 3). Now compare: 8/12 and 9/12. Since 8 < 9, we know 2/3 < 3/4.'

'Another strategy: use 1/2 as a BENCHMARK. Is the fraction more or less than 1/2? 3/8 is less than 1/2 (since 4/8 = 1/2). 5/6 is more than 1/2 (since 3/6 = 1/2). So 3/8 < 5/6 without even finding a common denominator!'

slides.prompt: Compare each pair using fraction strips first, then verify with common denominators. Write <, >, or = between them: (1) 1/2 __ 2/5, (2) 3/4 __ 5/8, (3) 2/3 __ 4/6, (4) 1/4 __ 2/6, (5) 5/6 __ 7/8, (6) 3/5 __ 2/3. Show your work finding common denominators for each pair. Circle any pairs that are equivalent.

slides.text: Comparing fractions is a skill you will use all the time — in cooking (is 3/4 cup more than 2/3 cup?), in measurement, and in math problems. Remember your three strategies: same numerator (smaller denominator wins), common denominators (convert and compare), and the benchmark test (compare to 1/2). With practice, you will compare fractions quickly and confidently.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare fractions using fraction strips, find common denominators, and use comparison symbols correctly?

parent_notes: Fraction comparison is a major milestone in mathematical thinking. Children often incorrectly assume that bigger numbers mean bigger fractions (thinking 1/8 > 1/4 because 8 > 4). The fraction strips provide crucial visual correction. The three strategies (same numerator, common denominator, benchmark to 1/2) give children multiple tools. Start with manipulatives and gradually move toward numerical strategies. Common errors: finding a common denominator but only converting one fraction, or multiplying numerators and denominators by different numbers.

title: The Muscular System — How Muscles Make Us Move
description: Children learn about the muscular system, discovering that muscles work in pairs to move bones. They explore the three types of muscles (skeletal, smooth, cardiac) and observe how their own muscles contract and relax.
instructions:
1. Review: The skeleton provides the framework. But what makes the skeleton MOVE? MUSCLES.
2. Demonstrate: bend your arm. Feel the bicep tighten (contract). Straighten your arm — feel the tricep tighten. Muscles work in PAIRS.
3. Introduce three muscle types: skeletal (attached to bones, voluntary), smooth (organs, involuntary — stomach, intestines), cardiac (heart only, involuntary, never tires).
4. Experiment: Have the child squeeze a ball repeatedly. The hand gets tired — skeletal muscles fatigue. But your heart never stops!
5. Count and time squeezes to see how muscles tire.
6. Discuss: How do muscles get stronger? Exercise and good nutrition.
7. Child labels muscles on a diagram and writes about the three types.
8. Create a muscle movement log: try different movements and identify which muscles work.

slides.setup_instructions: Print a labeled muscle diagram showing major muscles (biceps, triceps, quadriceps, hamstrings, abdominals, deltoids). Print a blank version for the child. Have the stress ball ready for the fatigue experiment.

slides.text: 'On Tuesday we learned about our skeleton — 206 bones that support and protect us. But bones cannot move by themselves! You need MUSCLES. Your body has over 600 muscles, and they are responsible for EVERY movement you make — from running to blinking to breathing.'

'Watch this.' Bend your arm and feel the top of your upper arm. 'Feel that bump? That is your BICEP muscle contracting — getting shorter and tighter. It PULLS your forearm up. Now straighten your arm and feel the bottom of your upper arm. Your TRICEP is now contracting. Muscles work in PAIRS — one pulls one way, the partner pulls the other way.'

'There are three types of muscles. SKELETAL muscles are attached to bones. You control them — they are VOLUNTARY. SMOOTH muscles are inside your organs (stomach, intestines). They work automatically — INVOLUNTARY. CARDIAC muscle is only in your heart. It beats about 100,000 times a day and NEVER gets tired!'

Fatigue experiment: 'Squeeze this ball as fast as you can for 30 seconds. Count your squeezes.' Time it. 'Now rest for 10 seconds and do it again.' Compare counts. 'Your skeletal muscles get TIRED — they need rest and oxygen. But your cardiac muscle keeps going because it has its own special rhythm and blood supply.'

slides.prompt: Label these muscles on your blank diagram: biceps, triceps, deltoids (shoulders), abdominals, quadriceps (front thigh), hamstrings (back thigh), gluteus (seat). Color skeletal muscles red. Then create a movement chart: list 5 movements (throwing a ball, kicking, crunching, jumping, pushing a door) and write which muscles you use for each. In your notebook, write 3 sentences about each muscle type.

slides.text: Your muscular system is an incredible network of over 600 muscles working together. Skeletal muscles move your bones (you control them), smooth muscles keep your organs working (automatic), and your cardiac muscle pumps your heart without ever stopping. Together with the skeletal system, muscles let you do everything from running to writing to smiling.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate major muscles, explain how muscles work in pairs, and describe the three types of muscle tissue?

parent_notes: The muscular system pairs beautifully with the skeletal system from Tuesday. The hands-on approach — feeling your own muscles contract, doing the fatigue experiment — makes this lesson memorable. Children love discovering that smiling uses fewer muscles than frowning, or that the tongue is a muscle. The muscle-pair concept (agonist/antagonist) is important: bicep curls are a perfect demonstration. Connect to health: exercise makes muscles stronger, stretching keeps them flexible, and good nutrition provides fuel for muscle growth.

title: Folk Music from England — Songs of the Industrial Revolution
description: Children listen to and learn English folk songs from the Industrial Revolution era, exploring how music reflected the lives and feelings of working people. They discover that folk music tells stories of real life.
instructions:
1. Ask: What is folk music? (Music of the common people, passed down through generations, tells stories of everyday life.)
2. Explain that during the Industrial Revolution, workers sang songs about their lives, their hardships, and their hopes.
3. Listen to or sing a simplified version of an English folk song (e.g., 'The Weavers' Song' or 'Drill Ye Tarriers Drill').
4. Discuss the lyrics: What story does this song tell? What was life like for these workers?
5. Compare to folk music from other cultures the children have studied.
6. Clap the rhythm of the song. Identify the beat, tempo, and mood.
7. Learn a simple verse and chorus together.
8. Child writes their own folk-song verse about daily life.

items: Recording or video of English folk songs (age-appropriate)
slides.setup_instructions: Search for child-friendly versions of English folk songs such as 'Drill Ye Tarriers Drill,' 'The Spinning Wheel Song,' or traditional English folk tunes. Print the lyrics large enough to read easily. Preview all songs for age-appropriateness.

slides.text: 'We have been learning about the Industrial Revolution — how machines changed the world. But what about the PEOPLE? How did workers FEEL about their lives? One way we know is through their MUSIC. FOLK MUSIC is music made by ordinary people. It tells stories of real life — joys, sorrows, work, and hope.'

'During the Industrial Revolution, factory workers, miners, and laborers sang songs while they worked. The songs had a steady BEAT that matched the rhythm of their work. Some songs were sad, telling of hard times. Some were funny, making fun of bosses. Some were hopeful, dreaming of a better life.'

Play or sing a folk song together. Follow along with the lyrics. 'What story is this song telling? Who is singing? What do they want? How do they feel?' Discuss the content of the lyrics and what they reveal about the singer's life.

'Listen to the RHYTHM of this song. Clap along with the beat. Is it fast or slow? Is the mood happy, sad, determined, or something else? Folk songs often have a simple melody that is easy to remember because they were passed from person to person by SINGING, not by writing down notes.'

slides.prompt: Write your own folk-song verse (4-6 lines) about YOUR daily life. Folk songs tell simple, honest stories. What do you do every day? What do you enjoy? What do you wish for? Try to make it rhyme and give it a steady rhythm you could clap to. Then illustrate your verse with a drawing showing the scene your song describes.

slides.text: Folk music is the voice of the people. Through these songs, we hear what life was really like for ordinary people during the Industrial Revolution. Music has always been a way for people to express their feelings, share their stories, and find comfort. Every culture has its folk music, and it connects us across time.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what folk music is, describe how Industrial Revolution songs reflected workers' lives, and identify the rhythm and mood of a folk song?

parent_notes: Connecting music to history deepens understanding of both. Folk music is an accessible entry point — the melodies are simple and the stories are clear. Children's folk song collections are available online and at libraries. If you play an instrument, accompany the singing. The songwriting activity encourages creative expression while reinforcing the lesson's themes. This also connects to the Montessori cosmic education narrative: humans have always used music to express their experience and build community.

title: Meal Planning in Action — Grocery Lists and Budgeting
description: Children extend their meal planning skills by creating detailed grocery lists from their planned menus, estimating costs, and learning to compare prices. They practice real-world math while developing practical household management skills.
instructions:
1. Review the meal plans from Tuesday's lesson.
2. Demonstrate: Go through one day's meals and list every ingredient needed.
3. Organize the grocery list by category: produce, dairy, grains, protein, pantry items.
4. Discuss: What do we already have at home vs. what we need to buy?
5. Estimate prices for items. Use a grocery flyer or online prices.
6. Add up the estimated total for one day's meals.
7. Discuss strategies for saving money: seasonal produce, store brands, sales.
8. Child completes a categorized grocery list with estimated prices for 3 days of meals.
materials_needed: Grocery store flyer or price list

items: Meal plans created in the previous practical life lesson
Grocery store flyer or printout of common prices
slides.setup_instructions: Gather the meal plans from the earlier lesson. Look up or estimate common grocery prices. If available, use a real grocery store flyer. Create categories for the grocery list: produce, dairy, grains/bread, meat/protein, pantry staples, frozen.

slides.text: 'On Tuesday we planned balanced meals. Now comes the next step: turning that plan into a GROCERY LIST. A good grocery list saves time at the store, makes sure you do not forget anything, and helps you stay on budget. Let us start with your Day 1 meals.'

'For each meal, we list EVERY ingredient. If breakfast is scrambled eggs with toast and orange juice, we need: eggs, butter, bread, and orange juice. But wait — do we already HAVE some of these at home? Check first! Only list what you need to BUY.'

'Now let us organize. Grocery stores are arranged in sections: produce together, dairy together, meats together. If our list is organized the SAME way, shopping is faster. Group your items: PRODUCE (fruits and vegetables), DAIRY (milk, cheese, yogurt), GRAINS (bread, pasta, rice), PROTEIN (meat, eggs, beans), PANTRY (oil, spices, canned goods).'

'Finally, let us estimate COSTS. A dozen eggs costs about $3, a loaf of bread about $4, a pound of chicken about $5. Write the estimated price next to each item. Add them up. This is your BUDGET — how much the meals will cost. Can you find ways to save? Store brands, sales, and seasonal produce all help!'

slides.prompt: Create a complete, organized grocery list for your 3-day meal plan. Organize items into categories (produce, dairy, grains, protein, pantry). Estimate the price of each item. Add up the total cost. Then answer: What is the total estimated cost for 3 days of meals? What is the average cost per day? Can you find two ways to reduce the total cost without losing nutrition?

slides.text: You just did what every household has to do: plan meals, write a grocery list, and estimate a budget. These are real-life skills that combine math, nutrition, and organization. The next time your family goes grocery shopping, offer to help make the list. You know how!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create an organized grocery list from a meal plan, estimate costs for items, and calculate a total budget?

parent_notes: This lesson beautifully integrates math (addition, estimation, budgeting), language (list-making, categorization), and practical life skills. Consider actually taking the child grocery shopping with their list as a follow-up activity. Comparing estimated prices to real prices is a powerful learning experience. If the child is ready, introduce the concept of cost per unit (which is the better deal: the small box or the large box?). This Montessori practical life work builds independence, confidence, and real-world competence.

title: Suffixes — Changing Words with -ful, -less, -ness, -ment
description: Children learn that suffixes are word parts added to the end of a word to change its meaning or part of speech. They study four common suffixes and discover how adding a suffix can turn a noun into an adjective or a verb into a noun.
instructions:
1. Review prefixes from Thursday. Prefixes go at the BEGINNING. Today: SUFFIXES go at the END.
2. Write 'care' on the board. Add '-ful' to make 'careful.' Add '-less' to make 'careless.' How do the meanings differ?
3. Teach four suffixes: -ful (full of), -less (without), -ness (state of being), -ment (action or result).
4. Examples: helpful, hopeless, kindness, excitement.
5. Notice: suffixes can change the part of speech. Care (noun) + -ful = careful (adjective). Kind (adjective) + -ness = kindness (noun).
6. Word building: Start with base words and add suffixes.
7. Child creates a suffix chart matching the prefix chart from Thursday.
8. Combine knowledge: Can we add BOTH a prefix AND a suffix? unhelpful, unkindness.

items: Base word cards: care, hope, thank, help, kind, dark, happy, sad, enjoy, excite, move, amaze, agree, treat
slides.setup_instructions: Create suffix cards and base word cards on index cards. The child will physically combine them. Have the prefix chart from Thursday visible so the child can see both sets of word parts.

slides.text: 'On Thursday we learned about PREFIXES — word parts added to the BEGINNING of a word. Today we learn about SUFFIXES — word parts added to the END. A suffix changes the meaning of a word, and sometimes changes what KIND of word it is. Watch!'

Write 'care' on the board. 'Care is a noun — a thing. Now I add -FUL: careful. Full of care. It is an adjective now — it describes someone. Now I add -LESS instead: careless. Without care. Also an adjective, but with the OPPOSITE meaning! Same base word, two suffixes, two very different words.'

'Let us learn four suffixes. -FUL means FULL OF: thankful, hopeful, helpful. -LESS means WITHOUT: homeless, careless, hopeless. -NESS means STATE OF BEING: kindness, darkness, happiness. -MENT means ACTION OR RESULT: excitement, movement, amazement.'

'Now here is something amazing: you can add BOTH a prefix AND a suffix to the same word! Care + -less = careless. Un- + careless = uncareless? No — we say CARELESSNESS. Un- + help + -ful = unhelpful. You are building words like building blocks!'

slides.prompt: Create a SUFFIX CHART matching your prefix chart. Four columns: -ful (full of), -less (without), -ness (state of being), -ment (action/result). List at least 5 words for each suffix. Then try building COMPLEX words using both a prefix and a suffix: start with base words (kind, help, agree, care) and see how many combinations you can make. Write each word and its meaning.

slides.text: Prefixes and suffixes are powerful word-building tools. With the four prefixes from Thursday (un-, re-, pre-, dis-) and the four suffixes from today (-ful, -less, -ness, -ment), you can decode and build hundreds of words. You are becoming word architects — building meaning piece by piece!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child define the four suffixes, add them to base words to create new words, and explain how suffixes can change a word's part of speech?

parent_notes: Suffix study complements the prefix work and builds morphological awareness — understanding that words are made of meaningful parts. The -ful/-less pair is especially powerful because they create opposite meanings from the same base. Watch for spelling changes when adding suffixes: happy becomes happiness (y changes to i), excite becomes excitement (drop the e). Do not over-correct during the creative building activity — the goal is playful exploration of word parts.
